current_workarounds: Buying individual vitamins from brands with third-party testing (expensive, complex)

Accepting that 'supplements are a scam' and doing nothing (resignation)

AG1.greespi_advantage: Flash-frozen whole food vs dried powder = preserved bioactivity. Transparent third-party testing vs proprietary blend.
AG1.switching_trigger: Proof that freezing preserves nutrient structure vs drying

Huel.perception: Synthetic meal replacement, not a health product
Huel.greespi_advantage: Real food nutrients vs lab-created vitamins. Not trying to replace meals, enhancing real food diet.

Individual supplements.perception: More control but overwhelming complexity and cost
Individual supplements.greespi_advantage: Comprehensive nutrition in whole food form vs managing 8+ separate bottles. Natural cofactor preservation.

Traditional multivitamins.perception: Low absorption, mostly excreted, false sense of security
Traditional multivitamins.greespi_advantage: Whole food matrix vs isolated compounds. Cellular structure intact vs destroyed by heat/compression.
Traditional multivitamins.switching_trigger: Studies showing absorption rates of frozen vs tablet forms

switching_barriers: 'I've been burned before' - fear of another $300+ disappointment
'How is this actually different?' - need mechanistic explanation, not marketing
'Frozen sounds inconvenient' - logistics concerns about storage/preparation
'Probably just as overhyped' - default skepticism toward all supplement claims
'What if it doesn't work for me?' - need risk-free trial
'How do I know it's actually frozen fresh vs frozen garbage?' - sourcing transparency
evaluation_process: 2. Read negative reviews before positive ones
3. Look for third-party lab testing (Labdoor, ConsumerLab)
4. Search for peer-reviewed research on freezing vs drying nutrients
5. Calculate cost per serving vs current supplement stack
6. Check refund policy and guarantee terms
7. Look for conflicts of interest in reviews
8. Ask in r/Supplements for unbiased opinions
9. Check if company is transparent about sourcing
10. Trial with lowest commitment (1 month if possible)

category_beliefs.bioavailability: Most people don't absorb what's on the label. Synergy and food matrix matter more than individual nutrient amounts.
category_beliefs.marketing_claims: If it sounds too good to be true, it is. Trust data, not testimonials.
category_beliefs.frozen_supplements: Interesting concept but skeptical about whether freezing actually preserves bioavailability vs marketing claim. Need to see the science.
category_beliefs.supplements_generally: 90% are snake oil designed to separate hopeful people from their money. Industry is predatory and unregulated.
category_beliefs.testing_and_regulation: FDA doesn't regulate supplements. Third-party testing is the only way to trust what's actually in the product.
category_beliefs.whole_food_supplements: 'Whole food' is usually marketing BS - it's still dried and processed into pills. Not meaningfully different.

current_workarounds: Rotating between 3-4 different probiotic brands every month, tracking symptoms in Notion/spreadsheets, buying research-grade supplements from Nootropics Depot, following Rhonda Patrick's protocols, using elimination diet + reintroduction, checking examine.com for every ingredient, joining clinical trials for free access to testing
vs_competitors: AG1: Too expensive ($99/mo), proprietary blend means can't verify dosing. Seed: Good science but limited to probiotics, $50/mo. Spirulina tablets: Cheap but heavy metal concerns, no testing transparency. Athletic Greens alternatives: Similar issues with proprietary blends. Greespi advantage: Frozen = live organisms (not freeze-dried), third-party testing required, microalgae = whole-food matrix (not isolated compounds), specific to gut-brain axis (not general wellness), transparent sourcing and testing.
switching_barriers: Current stack already working somewhat (sunk cost in testing what works), switching means losing baseline data (hard to compare), unfamiliar brand means research time investment, concern about gut microbiome disruption from changes, already committed to annual subscriptions elsewhere, need to see convincing data before trying another supplement
evaluation_process: 1) Deep research phase (2-3 weeks): PubMed searches, Reddit threads, examine.com, systematic reviews. 2) Cost-benefit spreadsheet: price per serving, bioavailable compounds, third-party testing. 3) Small test order (1 month) with strict baseline tracking. 4) A/B testing protocol: track 5+ biomarkers daily, photograph results. 5) Community validation: check experiences in QS forums. 6) Decide after 90 days minimum (proper trial length). 7) Annual re-evaluation against new alternatives.
category_beliefs: Most supplements are under-regulated snake oil with zero evidence. Gut health is the most impactful lever for overall health (based on microbiome research 2015-2024). Whole-food sources > isolated compounds (matrix effects matter). Live/frozen > freeze-dried > powdered (viability data supports this). Third-party testing is non-negotiable (heavy metals in spirulina are real). N=1 experimentation is required (everyone's microbiome is different). Premium pricing is justified IF transparency and testing prove it.
